docs.snippet: A paramount virtue in journalism is being the first to reveal startling facts. Editors notice. Colleagues notice. Competitors notice.    Except when they do not....
docs.lead_paragraph: A paramount virtue in journalism is being the first to reveal startling facts. Editors notice. Colleagues notice. Competitors notice. Except when they do not.
docs.abstract: Article profiles Bethany McLean, Fortune magazine financial writer who was first journalist to raise questions about Enron's balance sheet; she was first to reveal in article published 10 months ago absence of crucial information in company's financial reports; comments; photo (M)

headline.main: 10 Months Ago, Questions on Enron Came and Went With Little Notice

docs.snippet: Enron's accounting firm told Congress today that the company had engaged in ''possibly illegal acts'' before its collapse and misled its auditors by withholding crucial information.    Enron executives, meanwhile, presented a plan for the company ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Enron's accounting firm told Congress today that the company had engaged in ''possibly illegal acts'' before its collapse and misled its auditors by withholding crucial information. Enron executives, meanwhile, presented a plan for the company to survive by spinning off its prized energy-trading operation and emerging as a more conventional energy producer and wholesaler.
docs.abstract: Joseph P Berardino, chief executive of Arthur Andersen, longtime Enron Corp auditor, tells Congress that Enron engaged in 'possibly illegal acts' before its collapse and misled auditors by withholding critical information; acknowledges that Andersen auditors made mistakes with 'professional judgement about appropriate accounting treatment of Enron entities; Enron claims it always fully cooperated with Andersen personnel; Enron executives in New York present creditors with plan for company to survive by spinning off its prized energy-trading operations and emerging as more convention energy producer and wholesaler (M)

headline.main: Enron Auditor Raises Specter of Crime

byline.original: By JOSEPH KAHN with JONATHAN D. GLATER

docs.snippet: What is the penalty for walking away from the altar?    In suing Dynegy in bankruptcy court, Enron asserted that it should be awarded ''no less than $10 billion in damages.'' It said it was owed that amount because Dynegy had broken off its propos...
docs.lead_paragraph: What is the penalty for walking away from the altar? In suing Dynegy in bankruptcy court, Enron asserted that it should be awarded ''no less than $10 billion in damages.'' It said it was owed that amount because Dynegy had broken off its proposed merger without good reason.
docs.abstract: Analysis of Enron Corp's suit against Dynegy for breaking off proposed merger; Enron seeks $10 billion, far more that $350 million Dynegy would have had to pay if its shareholders rejected deal; holds Dynegy's statement that it was continuing its 'due diligence' after it signed merger deal scared investors, led its customers to refuse to trade with it and left Enron helpless when Dynegy did end merger (M)

headline.main: Looking for Judgment On a Shattered Deal

docs.snippet: An executive of the Toshiba Corporation said yesterday that negotiations on two joint-venture power plants in the western Indian state of Maharashtra were at a standstill because of the state's decision to scrap a $2.8 billion power project starte...
docs.lead_paragraph: An executive of the Toshiba Corporation said yesterday that negotiations on two joint-venture power plants in the western Indian state of Maharashtra were at a standstill because of the state's decision to scrap a $2.8 billion power project started by the Enron Corporation. Hideo Godo, a director of Toshiba, said at a meeting of industrialists that the Japanese consortium was awaiting a final decision on the Enron project. The Maharashtra government scrapped the Enron project early this month, citing high costs. The Japanese power project is to be undertaken in cooperation with the Maharashtra State Electricity Board.

headline.main: International Briefs; Toshiba Hits Snag On India Power Plants

docs.snippet: The suit filed against Goldman Sachs by the Securities and Exchange Commission helped sway opinion in favor of a regulatory overhaul of Wall Street....
docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes there really are coincidences. Those who campaign for greater financial regulation have benefited from two of them over the last decade. In each case, the coincidence offset a lot of expensive lobbying, Floyd Norris writes in his latest column in The New York Times.
docs.abstract: The suit filed against Goldman Sachs by the Securities and Exchange Commission helped sway opinion in favor of a regulatory overhaul of Wall Street.

headline.main: Norris: S.E.C.'s Timing Seals Overhaul Deal

docs.snippet: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collaps...
docs.lead_paragraph: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collapsed, taking with it the fortunes and retirement savings of thousands of employees. Tomorrow is the first day of the trial of Mr. Lay, who as founder and chairman is accused of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy, and Mr. Skilling, his chief executive, who faces dozens of counts, including fraud, conspiracy and insider trading.
docs.abstract: Article on 10 major figures in Enron trial and where they are now; says Nancy Temple, who joined accounting firm Arthur Andersen in 2000, sent e-mail message to Andersen employees about firm's document retention policy; prosecutors contend message was subtle signal to destroy Enron-related files; Temple continues to practice law in Chicago; photo (M)

headline.main: 10 Enron Players: Where They Landed After the Fall

docs.snippet: What's the best way to deter corporate malfeasance? Fining the board of directors may not be the best way to go....
docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT'S the best way to deter corporate malfeasance? In China, they've decided to try the death penalty. The former chief executive of the Bank of China's Hong Kong subsidiary was given a suspended death sentence recently for embezzlement, although if he behaves himself for a couple of years it will probably be commuted merely to life imprisonment. We've decided to get tough in this country, too. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 imposed tougher penalties for a variety of financial offenses. It also mandates harsher punishment for corporate officials who falsely certify a company's financial statements.

headline.main: Fining the Directors Misses the Mark

docs.snippet: From a business point of view, Enron is a smoking ruin. But there's important evidence in the rubble.    If Enron hadn't collapsed, we might still have only circumstantial evidence that energy companies artificially drove up prices during Californ...
docs.lead_paragraph: From a business point of view, Enron is a smoking ruin. But there's important evidence in the rubble. If Enron hadn't collapsed, we might still have only circumstantial evidence that energy companies artificially drove up prices during California's electricity crisis. Because of that collapse, we have direct evidence in the form of the now-infamous Enron tapes -- although the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Justice Department tried to prevent their release.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column examines charges by Rep Chris Bell of Texas that Majority Leader Tom DeLay laundered illegal corporate contributions for use in Texas elections; contends DeLay's quest for money for that effort led to Enron, which helped launch DeLay's political action committee because DeLay was helping firm's effort to secure energy deregulation legislation; says larger picture is that DeLay and his fellow hard-liners, who have forged immensely effective alliance with corporate interests, could achieve long-term lock on power (M)
